description: First attested in 1730. Origin uncertain, perhaps of Cornish origin (recorded as blogon c. 1450) or from Middle French bougeon, a diminutive of bouge (“club, stick”).

entries.meaning: A short, heavy club, often of wood, which is thicker or loaded at one end.
examples: We smashed the radio with a steel bludgeon.

verbs.description: bludgeon (third-person singular simple present bludgeons, present participle bludgeoning, simple past and past participle bludgeoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike or hit with something hard, usually on the head; to club.
examples: The apprehended rioter was bludgeoned to death.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To coerce someone, as if with a bludgeon.
examples: Their favorite method was bludgeoning us with the same old arguments in favor of their opinions.
